awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Cloud-Based Voice Analysis and Machine Learning to Improve Teaching with Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase I project will study how teachers use data to improve their instruction. In response to widespread understanding that feedback is a necessary component to improvement, school districts are increasingly investing in teacher coaches to provide feedback critical for teachers. However, this is not scalable, and typically only new or underperforming teachers have access to coaching. Earshot seeks to scale and democratize some aspects of coaching so every teacher can have access to the personalized data and feedback necessary for improvement. The goal is for all teachers to maximize their potential, better engaging students in learning.

Earshot has developed a cloud-based system using voice analysis to provide data about instruction. The core innovation is a machine learning process to listen to dialogue between teachers and students and analyze the quality of the educational exchange. Funding for this project would enable study of two critical questions: How does providing data about teacher behavior affect what teachers do in their classrooms? And, what kinds of resources, content, and support are necessary to help teachers improve? This research has the potential to transform the way teachers use data about their own performance and receive the necessary help to improve.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earshot LLC developed patent-pending technology to provide teaches with data about their instruction using voice analysis and machine learning. This project sought to understand how providing this type of data to teachers about their instructional practices through a smartphone app might impact teaching and learning in the classroom.

Earshot built upon functionality of the Earshot app, developing the ability to share data among users, and worked with an outside research partner to design an exploratory study to test Earshot’s theory of change which states: If teachers receive high quality, timely data on specific elements of their teaching, and have time to reflect on it, they will change/improve their teaching in those areas. Additionally, reflecting on their data with other teachers will increase the likelihood that teachers will change/improve their practice in those areas.

Initial testing of the Earshot app with teachers showed that teachers were enthusiastic about its possibilities for ownership of their own learning, generating conversations about instruction with their peers and increasing student engagement in their classrooms. However, this exploratory study of longer term use of the app in classrooms shows that additional design thinking would be required to make the app work for teachers to use it regularly and integrate it into their daily teaching routine and ongoing reflections, individual and collaborative, about their teaching.
